Intro.text: Defined by the World Health Organization to include 6 stages of development.  At stage 6, a pandemic is is reached.

Definition.text: A pandemic is the rapid spread of disease to a large population spread across a large region outside of normal local boundaries within a short period of time (1-2 weeks)

Phase_I.text: Phase I is the period before any new infectious subtypes have been detected in animals, a stage that is often missed since new subtypes are occur yearly

Phase_II.text: Phase II  begins after the new virus has been shown to infect humans

Phase_III.text:
Phase 3 begins when cases of the new virus appear in humans throughout the world for example during H5NI virus, or avian flu, a disease that spread from birds to humans but not from humans to humans.
[1]

Phase_IV.text: Phase IV occurs when the virus can easily transmit between humans and results in this results in community-level epidemics

Phase_V.text:
Phase V involves disease spread across continents and WHO regions
[2]
and often is inevitibel until true pandemic is reached.

Phase_VI.text:
Phase VI is the definition of a pandemic and requires documentation of the disease in multiple continents or two WHO regions
[2]
